tn.ref: a man's relative comes to take their bodies up—the one who is to cremate them after bringing the corpses out of the house—if he says to the person in the house, "Is ... you?"
tn.text: The meaning of these words is not clear. Possible meanings: 1) The "man's relative" is the one who will "take their bodies up" and "cremate ... the corpses," and he speaks to a person who hid in the house after the ten family members died. 2) The "man's relative" who "comes to take their bodies up" is a different person from "the one who is to cremate ... the corpses," and they talk to each other in the house: "a man's relative comes to take their bodies up with the one who will burn the corpses after they have been brought out of the house—if while they are in the house the relative says to the burner of the corpses, 'Is ... you?'"
burn a dead body
dead bodies
"Listen" or "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you."

tn.ref: the big house will be smashed to pieces, and the little house to bits
tn.text: These two phrases share similar meanings. The contrast between "the big house" and "the little house" means that this refers to all houses. Possible meanings: 1) Yahweh will command others to destroy every house or 2) Yahweh himself will destroy every house himself simply by giving a command. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: the big house will be smashed to pieces
tn.text: AT: "the enemy will smash the big house to pieces" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
You can use the same word for both of these phrases.
AT: "the little house will be smashed to bits" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Amos uses two rhetorical questions to draw attention to the rebuke that follows.

tn.ref: Do horses run on the rocky cliffs?
tn.text: It is impossible for a horse to run on rocky cliffs without getting hurt.  Amos uses this rhetorical question to rebuke them for their actions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Does one plow there with oxen?
tn.text: One does not plow on rocky ground. Amos uses this rhetorical question to rebuke them for their actions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Yet you have turned justice into poison
tn.text: "But you make laws that hurt innocent people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: and the fruit of righteousness into bitterness
tn.text: "and you punish those who do what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
